author: Rollmottle
content:
Been trying to think of a way in to the question about what I did without being completely frustrating or giving a list of moves that don't mean anything outside of the context of being in my chair, hearing what and how I hear.

This process for this song is like any other...listen for what the song needs and act accordingly. That's the frustrating answer but it's also true. What did you do? "I mastered it." lol

But I know that's not what you're asking. For a track like this, I'm primarily focused on the vocal and how it's sitting and feeling. The vocal performance is incredibly dynamic and intimate. This one had some ringy stuff through 2.5k and in the upper mid range that I felt was detracting from the "fireside" intimacy. The goal was to take off some of the edge without stepping on the presence. That was a combo of RX and EQ. 

On this song, I did an analog pass because I am usually able to manage to get the balance of presence and de-edge I'm looking for very quickly. Since time was of the essence here, that was the move. Couple of moves on Equilibrium digitally before the Gyraf and Porter Grinder in the analog chain. The "trickiest" thing I did here was flip the Porter Grinder into M/S to bring the vocal closer into the center (by cutting!) and to push the mellotron and atmospherics to the sides (by boosting). All very subtle stuff.

So, there were some moves here, but the moves were all in service of the feeling the song was telling me it needed. We talk a lot about monitoring here. When you can connect to the song and walk around inside of it, it's much easier to know what you need to do (or not to do) to bring it to life.

author: Rollmottle
content:
nah, fuck -1 or -2. theoretically the lower the ceiling, the less risk there is of intersample peaks happening upon conversion to MP3 or some other lossless format streamers use to stream audio to your device. even if there are ISP's, they usually light up a meter but are inaudible. i live at -0.5db for most everything. sometimes i'll go to -0.3db if it's something that is pop oriented (this is where i landed for @thejadenmejia's single for example). i think a lot of the panic about it is overblown. in the real world, clients like their shit loud.

as far as distro goes, i know some are starting to accept higher res files or even accepting multiple files. my deliverables have always been 96/24 and 44/16. I've recently started including 44/24's. i've always discouraged submitting anything other than 44/16 because who knows what some of these services are doing with SRC and dither, but i think with the advent of high res and lossless delivery, you are well-advised to submit the higher bit-rate files nowadays. all that said, with something like 44/24 you are probably pretty safe from getting your shit munched down-funnel.

author: cian riordan
content: Howie is amazing. A total nut. But a total gem. The first record I worked on with EV almost 15 years ago was a Taking Back Sunday album. We finished the record and had it mastered by Brian Gardener and Eric wasn't super happy -- we had just found out that Howie moved to town and was up at Steven Slate's place so we paid a visit. Eric asked if he'd take a swing a song and he just absolutely crushed it. So we gave him the album and what we got back was hilarious: totally mismatched levels from song to song, some L&R balances totally off whack. Eric ended up going to his studio to figure out what the hell was going on and found all of his shit just wildly out of calibration (he was mastering from 1/2"). Ended up getting it across the line... the album sounded great, but the experience was... an experience. That being said, super fond memories and he's a lovely guy.

author: cian riordan
content: Ruairi's gonna come on here and shellac me in a few, but I'm of reasonably stable mind and don't believe that people are setting up proper tests when matching converters (level calibration, having the ability to actually go back and forth between them instantly, etc). The idea that there's a dramatic sonic difference between any reasonably spec'd modern converter is just insane to me. I've gone down the rabbit hole for years with comparative listening with converters, clocks, etc and I've built my own conclusions --  I hope everyone here has a chance to do that as well instead of just taking people's word on the internet for how many thousands of dollars people should spend on boutique A/D/A.

author: manyonline
content: I do a trick using Pro Tools Audiosuite where I send the main mix, instrumental, TV, voc up, etc all at once.  RX sees this as a surround file and I can do the edits to all files at once. author: masteredbyjack
content:
As a follow up to this (most of us here know it, but I see it is a common misconception out in the Wild Wild West):

32bit will allow any over 0s to be represented in the file — if you print at 24bit and there are overs, those overs go to 0, it’s not exactly clipping like we might think of it but like it.

The tricky part is people can monitor above 0 in their DAW since it is at 64bit usually, then if they print at 24bit the overs are sent to 0

author: Ross Fortune
content:
On that note, can't remember where I found this but a related piano recipe from Michael Brauer. Hoping he hasn't trademarked this one so the Discord doesn't get shut down.



"Remember the early Elton John records? Remember how his piano shimmered? At mediasound we loved that sound so a lot of us were always playing around with getting different versions of it. No lacquered hammers, no Dolby A off, just a combination of compression and EQ.


I only recorded Luther's voice, may he rest in peace, on that song along with "searching" and then mixed both. Luther was on a whole other level of singers. He walked into that session and listened to the song in the control room once, then he walked out into the studio with the lyric sheet in his hand. What you hear on"Glow of Love" and "searching" is his first fun down reading the lyrics from a yellow pad. No punches.


The piano sound you’re referring to is probably the same one that I did for Vandross on the “Never too much” song.


Ok, this is how you do it.

1. First insert an LA3A or LA2A (depending on the version of sound you’re going after) across the stereo piano tracks. The LA2A is good if the song is slow and the chords are quarter notes. The LA3A is good if the chords are faster with a harder attack like in “never too much”. Bang those meters and 
2. out of the compressor go into a couple of pultecs and push up..way up the 3 or 5 k on the low end and the 8 or 10 k on the high end. Don’t be safe. 
3. Now go to the desk EQ and start clearing out some of the muddiness and EQ up the remaining mids so that it just shimmers like a baby. 
4. When it’s done right, you can hear the harmonics riding up during each sustain.  
5. I remember hearing that song on the radio and man that piano was making me feel good all over. Sounds pretty simple when you know how to do it right?”

author: Rollmottle
content:
I’ve found it easier to separate the tonal decisions from loudness decisions. I take the limiter out of the equation when I am making tonal decisions. So in my case, it's a simple bypass of with processing vs. without to make the decisions against the mix. This is inherently level matched. This gets trickier with dynamics processing but that’s a simple offset of the processed mix. That’s all happening on the object in my DAW without need for additional plugins or routing. Since I am rarely compressing anyways, this is a low friction way of judging the moves against the mix. 

When I’m happy with that, I’ll print the pre-lim and then load it up on another track to do the limiting. When I’m happy with the limiting, I have a quick action to create an A/B track where I can load the hot mix or mix to see if I’m as loud or louder than it. 

None of this is by number or meter. It’s all by ear.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
On the more general topic of what @macca should do (or anyone else in their situation)...I'd say just forget about mastering at all. The approaches and mindset I'm using, if you have access to the mix...makes them irrelevant IMO. I'm also sorta opinionated on this though. Like...why worry about making a tiny .3 db cut with .7 Q to clear up the vocal range....when you could just cut the actual elements that are the problem...or just raise the vocal?

And almost certainly your monitoring won't let you hear these tiny moves enough to even learn probably. But I suppose there is some value is understanding the subtle balance shifts.

For me, many people can "master" their own track just fine for where they are at. It's not helpful at all for them to learn what a pro mastering engineer is doing day-to-day if they ever are only going to be "mastering" their mix. Why? It's like saying it's useful to learn the trumpet if you're ever only going to play piano IMO. Sure, it's still music but almost no skills will actually translate across. 

You can always fix it better on an individual track than on the stereo file.

I also sorta bristle at the what is "mastering" convo...we just finish records. That's it. Whatever it takes. Of course there are some broad approaches that will be applicable to everyone, but most of them would be better forgotten by mixers so they can make bolder and more creative moves.

Again, this is all just in my opinion, perhaps Ruairi is rubbing off on me lol? (notice strategic placing of lol @Nomograph Mastering )

I do like that first record a lot , so my response is defo biased by simply really loving the song and the artist 

The second one is totally not my wheelhouse 

I just wanted to note/counterpoint  where it seems you’ve caught a little heat for asking : 

I think there’s real value in being able to discuss what we’re hearing without feeling pressured to adopt a particular emotional stance or to measure our impressions against social circles or market outcomes. Honest listener reactions, offered respectfully, are part of how we learn as engineers. We can appreciate the creators’ dedication and still talk openly about the sonic choices we notice — those things aren’t in conflict. 

People like Jeff Ellis casually state that the shaker is way too loud on ‘Beat It,’ and no one sees that as disrespecting Bruce Swedien — it’s just part of how engineers talk about records. An honest  critique isn’t an ad hominem attack; it’s how we train our ears and learn from greats 

Technically , I’m 💯 with Johnathan’s point about monitoring and Anthony’s  about leaning in . 

The enemy of art is indifference . I love that you care enough to ask .

author: Berlin
content:
I keep it simple. No oversampling. Flip between modes (Hard clip, soft clip, etc) to see what gets you a better result for the program material. Like with anything, there is not a simply quantifiable reason for why some modes work and others don't, changing from song to song. Listen carefully and use your ears. 

I like to use Standard Clip for highly transient material, clipping off those really high peaks to take some of the work off of the proceeding limiter. But it is very easy to get audible clipping and distortions if you go too far (if that not is not your desired result), so keep an ear out! The meter doesn't help you with that, even if it doesn't *look* like you're clipping very much.

author: Nick Stetina
content:
I think this and file naming conventions is why I don’t actually use the external editor feature in WL, and instead just open a dupe of the original mix titled ‘Song Name_RX1’, instantiate the RX Monitor connection and just work in the RX window while it plays through the chain in WaveLab. Save in RX and the file is automatically overwritten, replace the mix file in WL with a few clicks.

This might be overkill but I have even left myself breadcrumbs along the way, RX1 pass focusing on the instrumentals, and then a second pass on vocals. That way if there is any undoing later, I have a checkpoint.

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
Ok so from what i can tell, Apple Digital Masters, (previously called MFiT), is basically just a series of guidelines that wants you to 

a) deliver the highest res wave file possible without up sampling
b) avoid clipping (so true peak + reduced ceiling + monitor any clipping through the tools they provide you)
c) preview that after your wav is encoded for Apple Music, you make sure it still sounds good. (the Master for Itunes droplet tool they give you)

If you want that "Apple Digital Master" badge, on the track, you likely have to get it done by someone certified to do an ADM master.

author: Moses Mastering
content:
So, in most cases, you can go over 0 dB in your DAW if you're working in 32-bit (or higher) precision, and you won’t necessarily hear the clipping. This is because the internal audio engine can handle peaks above 0 without immediate distortion—it’s all about floating-point processing magic.

Now, whether the audio gets normalized to stay under 0 dB depends on what happens during export. Sometimes, what you're seeing in the DAW or Ozone meters isn’t exactly what ends up in the final file—especially if there's a limiter, normalization, or post-processing involved. It’s even possible that the version you’re analyzing wasn’t actually the one that was officially released. Happens more often than you’d think!

That said, it’s not unusual to see mixes or masters that are technically clipping more so going over 0... in tools like Ozone or the DAW but sound fine due to the flexibility of floating-point processing. I’m not saying this is a best practice—but I’ve definitely played around with it. I’ve even intentionally clipped files way past 0 dB, re-exported them, and compared them to cleaner versions. They sounded different, but at that point, I found myself asking, “Why am I trying to squeeze one more dB of loudness out of something that’s already crushed and competitive?” Classic overthinking, right?

Anyway, back to your question: I think what you’re seeing is a product of the DAW working internally at 32- or 64-bit, so it can handle those overs without clipping during processing. Then, during export, maybe they normalized it, maybe they fixed it later, maybe it did just didn't sound distroted haha... or maybe that’s just not the real released version at all. Who knows?  I would not lose sleep over it and also know what you have seen is not a "secret" that your missing haha.

author: hebakadry
content: I think time spent de-essing vocals and treating HF content in vinyl prepped masters overrides worrying about how much limiting there is in my opinion. The amount of limiting and how good/bad the cut is really pertinent on the program material itself.  Not the actual amount of gain reduction you are doing because the cutter will literally just turn everything down anywhere between 8-10dB before the signal hits the amps. Excessive sibilance, on a hyper compressed rock record with insane splashy over compressed cymbals and out of control HF information will result in the dull cuts you get back from most plants where you don’t have access to the cutting engineer.  They do this because they want to create a playback safe record and avoid a very expensive $10k mistake like blowing a cutterhead if their amp breakers aren’t calibrated right.  Instead of spot de-essing problem on one song or spot treating problem songs on a side, they will opt for broad stroke moves (HF limiting, EQ, global de-essing) and that can be a bit of death sentence to the quality of the cut and put everyone off vinyl as a format.  Which I think is an incredible format with well crafted engineering.  Also I strongly believe that every record doesn’t belong on vinyl…but that’s another convo.

author: Eric Martin
content:
That is based on how the manufacturers calibrate where full scale is in terms of output which you’ll see referred to in a different language excuse the output is designed in volts not db, so in terms of voltage they’ll be able to cleanly supply more voltage than is necessary so that playback is always sounding as intended.

IE 0dbfs = 2.2 Volts peak to peak(positive and negative)

And lets say the amplifier can reproduce 3  Volts peak to peak, they’ve designed the device to handle any overs without distortion.

All of this is highly technical but involves maths and actual “audio engineering” in the geekiest of the geekery.

@David Fuller will understand much better than I do about it

author: hebakadry
content: If however you’re cutting at a plant like GZ media or any of their brokers (which everyone does now) for the high turnaround, where you cannot interface with the cutting engineer…yes you’re going to get a boring “safe cut”…meaning they will not go above and beyond or be creative and will avoid inner diameter distortion at all cost.  They have their own proprietary software and the lathe operator is literally in a different room from the person that actually processes the source material they get for the cut. Very much a setup made for speed factory cutting & efficiency and not so much for the craft.  There is an interesting video by Michael Fremer filmed at GZ…i think he’s the only person that was ever allowed in and it is by all means is an impressive operation.  They have a pretty advanced QC process.  But it’s a game of odds on whether your cut will sound good or not.  Half the time you’ll get a shit cut and the other time it might be fine…depends on which operator you get.  It’s treated like a product there and not so much a “craft”.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
This is true (at least as I understand it) but I think the deeper discussion revolves around how dense you want the music to be, how the transients sit relative to other aspects of the music, how much low end you want and what you’re willing to trade off in terms of openness/dynamics vs energy. 

This is a super deep topic that I’m still wrapping my head around and forming my own opinion…and while I know I argued earlier it’s important to consider your loudness, it should absolutely take a back seat to your feel for the music creatively IMO.

There are many complex reasons why people like things loud (some I agree with, some not) but they do and will continue to as far as I can see.

Something like LUFS I find is best rendered as background knowledge. For example I found it interesting Ruairi says he knows how loud a record is because he knows his room so well and doesn’t need to look at the meters. I’m still getting there but I feel that’s a best case scenario so the meters aren’t dictating feel

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Okay crew got a question on a scenario I’ve come upon often enough to ask:

A limited REF is given at 24 bit — but when the non-lim mix is given in 24bit it’s peaking at exactly 0.0db. 

Obviously there could be many explanations for this (if intentional, which is fine). But I’ve had it happen quite a few times where I have a close relationship with a mixer and thought it could be an oversight for reasons specific to each instance (not just generally seeing a peak of 0)— turns out when the non-lim 32 bit print is sent there are sure enough overs in there.

Typically i see it happen when they are going into limiters hot in the REF, obviously when they print non-lim there are overs. Talking big overs, +4db or whatever

BUT — honestly it doesn’t really sound “clipped” in the 24bit non-lim print — I’m assuming the overs are just recalibrated to zero but somehow this doesn’t sound bad? Of course, if I get the 32bit I find I can make it sound just as loud but “better” with the full waveform represented in the 32bit file.

It’s an easy fix — just get a 32 bit print without a limiter (if I can get in touch with who is handling that, which isn’t always the case).

I think (?) I understand what’s happening — DAWs operate at 64 or 32 and can handle the overs fine in the session, but upon render at 24bit they get chopped (not sure about wording).

Totally fine — I can and have handled it no problem, just a curiosity on what others are seeing, if I’m even on the mark about this and how (or if) you are handling it.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
I think it’s a little bit of a lot of things, and these are not ranked in importance 

- I work in a basically perfect room designed by Northward Acoustics
- I work great, relatively low distortion speakers (ATC SCM110)
- I worked at a fairly fixed level and it’s relatively quiet
- I don’t reference other stuff while I work
- A big one - I’m Mastering … taking mixes from ok to good or great, it’s way less chaotic and varied than producing or mixing where you can spend a lot longer in the weeds with weird sounds etc 
- I’ve been doing audio for 30 years so there’s less fight

I do absolutely remember being complete toast at the end of recording and mixing days when I was younger - shitty monitoring and acoustics, playing too loud, chasing my tail all contributed

Now, my ears basically never go. My brain does, I just get too tired to make decisions, or my body says “sleep please” but my ears just truck along thankfully

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
(copy/paste)

Assuming we're talking about fairly typical rock, pop and Hip Hop then this 3 part strategy covers a lot of ground

1) Make sure the EQ is as balanced as you can get it - most of your perceived loudness comes from the arrangement and mid range focus (2k to 8k). Too much low end will sound bad when you limit. Make sure the relationship between 80, 160 and 320 makes sense (think of them a little like fundamental, 1st and 2nd harmonic).

2) Consider shaving snare transients (and maybe kick transients) with a clipper. This spreads that peak energy harmonically across the spectrum, keeping energy, hiding in the noisey nature of snares and lets the limiter work less hard (I like SIR Standardclip - $25, great metering and responds intuitively). a dB or two of clipping will help the limiter work less.

3) Pro-L2 on the settings below is a great start point for clean and predictable limiting, raising input gain until you get the desired level
